page.title: 12Woodlands of Freshfield
page.content: THE ALDER WOODS There are surprisingly few alders. We saw Scots Pine, Balsam Poplar, Pussy Willow, Corsican Pine, Silver Birch, Common Hawthorn and Alder. Most of the hawthorn trees only reached the waist of our teacher. In a dark part of the wood, bats were flying about. One hung upside-down on a pine tree. Opposite was a robin's nest, burrowed in the sand on a grassy mound. In the nest were eggs and the bird flew out in our faces. THE PINE WOODS From 1914, Corsican pines have been planted on the land- ward side of the stabilised dunes. The trees were planted close together for commercial reasons but the plant- ations have since spread naturally due to trees re-seeding themselves. Gold- crests and red squirrels live here and many types of fungi, including puff- balls, grow in the shade of the trees.
